conclusion: The ego is neither formally nor materially in consciousness but is outside in the world like the ego of another
The transcendental ego is a useless and harmful hypothesis that should be rejected
Consciousness is always consciousness of something and this intentionality is its fundamental structure
Intentional objects are objects of consciousness including physical objects numbers values the psyche and psycho-physical persons
The consciousness which says I think is not the consciousness which thinks
Consciousness transcends its own properties because it includes both itself and the reflection of itself
Pre-reflective consciousness is impersonal and lacks a personal ego
The I appears only on the occasion of a reflective act and never in unreflective consciousness
When running after a streetcar or absorbed in contemplating a portrait there is no I present in consciousness
In unreflective consciousness the self has disappeared and been annihilated
Objects constitute the unity of consciousness not an underlying ego
Transcendental consciousness is an impersonal spontaneity
Nothing except consciousness can be the source of consciousness
Consciousness cannot be limited except by itself and is subject to no law but its own
A transcendental I would render consciousness heavy and ponderable
The ego is transcendent to consciousness not transcendental within it
The psychological ego and the transcendental ego are both equally transcendent to consciousness
The Ego is the ideal noematic and indirect unity of the infinite series of our reflected consciousnesses
The I is the Ego as the unity of actions while the me is the Ego as the unity of states and qualities
States and actions are the intended objects that constitute and support the Ego
Hatred is a projected unity created by multiple spontaneous conscious moments of rage toward something
Psychological dispositions are created by multiple manifestations of states through impure reflection
The Ego appears to reflection as a transcendent object realizing the permanent synthesis of the psychical
The Ego is on the same side as the psychical not as a subject pole behind consciousness
Reflective consciousness creates our empirical worldly self through acts of impure reflection
Through impure reflection consciousness traps itself in the illusion that the self was already there all along
Unreflected consciousness must be considered autonomous as a totality needing no completing at all
The character of unreflected desire is to transcend itself by apprehending on the object the quality of desirability
Even if the unconscious exists it could not contain spontaneities of a reflected sort
The definition of the reflected is that it be posited by a consciousness
The unreflected has an ontological priority over the reflected since it does not need to be reflected to exist
Reflection presupposes unreflective consciousness but unreflective consciousness needs no reflection to exist
Consciousness is always aware of its activity and experience without needing reflection
When an external object is perceived consciousness is also conscious of itself non-positionally
Non-positional consciousness of itself differs from positional consciousness directed at objects
A reflecting consciousness is in itself unreflected requiring a new third-degree act to posit it
There is no infinite regress since consciousness needs no reflecting consciousness to be conscious of itself
Consciousness simply does not posit itself as an object in its basic self-awareness
The I is an existent that proffers itself to an intuition of a special kind
The I is always apprehended inadequately behind the reflected consciousness
The transcendent I must fall before the phenomenological reduction
Having consciousness of this chair differs from I have consciousness of this chair
Personhood only enters the scene as the outcome of an anonymous process of constitution
Husserl ought to have stopped at one Ego the psychological worldly one since there is no other needed
The ego is nothing without something to contemplate but is reliant on itself and its being
The flexibility of consciousness is its ability to contemplate something in its absence
We can be conscious of a thing like another consciousness is conscious of it but cannot reflect on their being conscious of it
We cannot contemplate the intuitive apprehension of another consciousness
We become apprehensive about our awareness that we are to be responsible for our own doings
Intentional objects are both objects of consciousness and consciousness itself
The consciousness that can reflect on the mental concept of thinking is not the consciousness which thinks
One can think of ones own thinking like the idea that a painting of a pipe is not an actual pipe
Consciousness is in the world as we are conscious of things and also conscious of ourselves being conscious of things
Things and our own consciousness of things evoke our own reflective consciousness
The consciousness of reflection is not able to be reflected on without a further act
The material presence of things proves the ontology of the object contemplating them
Sartre's rejection of the transcendental ego provides the only possible refutation of solipsism
An impersonal self-consciousness helps with the fundamental problem of other minds
The transcendental ego creates the problem of knowing how others are capable of conscious states
Solipsism holds that all objects are projections from myself and only my ego exists
Sartre dissolves the solipsism problem by eliminating the transcendental subject whose knowledge we are certain of
Descartes wrongly claimed that in introspection we grasp a pre-existing I who thinks
The I only appears in the act of introspection when consciousness takes itself as its object
Our pre-reflective conscious experience is impersonal through and through
The self or ego is a post-hoc construction that transcends consciousness just as external objects do
Consciousness has no inside since it is not a substance carrying qualities with it
Mind is not a container that holds perceptions ideas or impressions
Consciousness is nothingness in the sense that there are no ideas perceptions or images in it
Consciousness is like a mirror that reflects all objects without containing them within itself
Intentionality restores to things their horror and their charm
Intentionality is intrinsically realistic letting the world appear to consciousness as it really is
Sartre adopts a realistic interpretation of intentionality against Husserls idealistic tendencies
The transparency or translucidity of consciousness would be disrupted by a transcendental ego
Husserls transcendental ego would pre-exist all particular actions threatening existentialist freedom
The notion of a self or ego is not given in experience but constructed through reflection
The Ego is the transcendent object of reflexive experience not the subject of pre-reflective experience
The impersonal or pre-personal character of consciousness stems from its non-egological structure
In absorbed activity I am plunged in the world of objects which constitute the unity of my consciousness
The tram appears as having-to-be-overtaken as its own mode of phenomenalization not my personal relation
The object presents itself as carrying objective properties strictly independent from ones personal relation to it
The streetcar is experienced as transcendent obliterating the subjective features of conscious experience
Pure consciousness is an impersonal transcendental field in which the self is produced
Consciousness disguises its monstrous spontaneity through the constitution of the ego
The natural attitude and the Ego mask from consciousness its own spontaneity
We immerse ourselves in the natural attitude to avoid the anguish that recognition of spontaneity would induce
Reflection poisons desire by transforming unreflected consciousness into reflected consciousness
On the unreflected level I come to Peters aid because Peter is needing-to-be-aided
When my state becomes reflected I am watching myself acting and it is no longer Peter who attracts me
It is not my fault if my reflective life poisons my spontaneous life in essence
The good that qualifies my behavior appears only in the reflected state
La Rochefoucaulds psychology is true only for feelings that originate from reflective life
Feelings given first as my feelings rather than transcended toward an object are products of reflection
The me appears only with the reflective act as the noematic correlative of a reflective intention
The I must not be sought in unreflected states of consciousness nor behind them
The Ego of which I and me are two faces constitutes the ideal unity of reflected consciousnesses
The psycho-physical me is a synthetic enrichment of the psychical Ego
When someone says I am an indecisive person it is not the psycho-physical me that is directly indicated
It would be tempting but wrong to constitute the Ego as a subject-pole like Husserls object-pole
Consciousness unifies itself through its intentional objects
It is consciousness which unifies itself as a complementary claim to unity through objects
Being and Nothingness describes a human reality living in bad faith according to clues in Transcendence of the Ego
Pure reflection differs from impure reflection in its relation to freedom and authenticity
Pre-reflective values differ from reflective values in their authenticity
It is possible to choose freedom instead of the desire to be God
The image is a form of consciousness not an object of consciousness
Imagination is nothing like perception despite the belief that imagining is like internal perception
Perception is necessarily incomplete since one can only see one side of a chair at a time
Perception involves observation and study over time of a particular object with our senses
Imagination is total presenting all sides of the imagined chair at once
Imaginary objects cannot teach us anything new since they contain only what we put into them
The totality of the imagined chair comes from a synthesis of our knowledge and intention toward it
We expect the chair to be X or Y and therefore in imagination it appears to us this way
What goes on when we picture something imaginary is quasi-observation not genuine observation
Imaginary objects are a melange of past impressions and recent knowledge
Imaginary objects are what we intend them to be
Because imaginary objects appear like perception we tend to treat them as if they were real
We are not deluded about imaginary objects but we ascribe emotions and beliefs to them as if real
Throughout the book Sartre argues against conceiving images as something inside a spatial consciousness
The illusion of immanence is the mistaken belief that images reside within consciousness spatially
The illusion of immanence comes from our habit of thinking in space and in terms of space
To say I have an image of Peter should not mean I have a portrait of Peter within consciousness
An image is implicitly but wrongly identified with the material object it represents
Humes definition of ideas as faint images of perceptions exemplifies the illusion of immanence
What is required for the imaginary process is an analogon or equivalent of perception
The analogon can be a painting photograph sketch or mental image we conjure
Through the imaginary process the analogon loses its own sense and takes on the sense of the object it represents
The photograph of my father ceases being colors on paper and stands in for my absent father
I ascribe the feelings I have about my father to the picture of him
An analogon can take on new qualities based on my own intention toward it
Because we can imagine we are ontologically free
A consciousness that could not imagine would be hopelessly mired in the real
Without imagination consciousness would be incapable of perceiving unrealized possibilities
Without imagination there could be no real freedom of thought or choice
To imagine consciousness must be able to posit an object as irreal or nonexistent or absent
The imaging consciousness posits its object as a nothingness
The image has wrapped within it a certain nothingness
However lively appealing or strong the image it gives its object as not being
There cannot be an intuition of nothingness precisely because nothingness is nothing
All consciousness intuitive or not is consciousness of something
Nothingness can be given only as an infrastructure of something
The aesthetic object is constituted and apprehended by an imaging consciousness that posits it as irreal
Aesthetic enjoyment is real but serves to constitute the imaginary object not the real painting
The real is never beautiful since beauty is a value applicable only to the imaginary
Beauty means the negation of the world in its essential structure
The imaginative act is at once constituting isolating and annihilating
Memory is consciousness directed toward the past positing its object as given-now as passed
Memory recalls events that did not undergo modification of irreality while flowing into the past
The memory is not evoked but recalled differing essentially from imagination
Image is of irreality whereas memory is of reality
Two sorts of futures exist one as temporal ground for present perception the other posited as not yet
Foresight based on real development from past to future remains within the realm of reality
Detaching the future from the present that constitutes its sense means cutting it off from reality
Presentifying as nothingness involves annihilating the severed future
The essential condition of imaging consciousness is having the possibility to posit a thesis of irreality
For consciousness to imagine it must escape the world by its very nature
Consciousness must be able to derive from itself a position of distance from the world
For consciousness to be able to imagine it must be free
Imagination is not an empirical power added to consciousness but the whole of consciousness realizing freedom
The neantisation that consciousness performs is the reverse side of its freedom
If consciousness were mired in the world with psychological determinism it could produce only the real
Any creation of the imaginary would be impossible for consciousness fully immersed in the world
Consciousness must be free to imagine and imagination is the entirety of consciousness realizing its freedom
Every apprehension of the real as a world tends to end up with the production of irreal objects
Apprehension of reality is always free nihilation of the world from a particular point of view
The noematic correlate of consciousness freedom is the world carrying possibility of negation
An image being negation of the world from a particular point of view can appear only on the ground of the world
The appearance of the image requires particular perceptions to be diluted in the syncretic wholeness of world
All of our engagements with the world have the potential to activate the imaginary process
Because the imaginary process relies on intentionality we constitute the world based on our intentions toward it
The world is constituted not from outside into consciousness but we constitute it based on intentions
Image portrait and caricature form a family of imaging consciousnesses
Signs differ from images in their relation to the signified object
Imitations occupy a position between sign and image in the spectrum of imaging consciousness
Schematic drawings represent a transition from sign to image
Faces seen in fire spots on walls and rocks in human form exemplify spontaneous image formation
Hypnagogic images and visions in crystal balls involve particular structures of imaging consciousness
The mental analogon consists of knowledge affectivity kinesthetic sensations and words
Knowledge specifies that the object is such or such adding determinations synthetically
Affectivity is essential to imagination though perception can lack affective structure
Kinesthetic sensations and bodily movements contribute to the constitution of mental images
Words play a role in mental imagery introducing new materials that make learning possible
In perception the object is always presented from only one side at a time with profiles to discover
In imagination knowledge is already contained within the image not to be discovered
The imaging consciousness is an act formed at a stroke by will or pre-willing spontaneity
Only pre-willing spontaneity can bring final developments from the imaging consciousness
Genuine feelings differ from imaginary feelings though imaginary feelings are not themselves irreal
Imaginary feelings appear only in the face of irreal objects and are degraded poor jerky and schematic
Imaginary feelings need non-being in order to exist
Acts of imagination are like magical acts similar to incantations making objects of desire appear
Dreams are not composed of mental images but have their own distinctive structure
The dream differs from mental imagery in its relation to perception and reality
In the dream the self is imaginary not the perceiving self of waking life
Hallucinations posit an imaginary stance to the world that deceives about the essence of experience
Drug-induced hallucinations give the experiencer will to embrace the imaginary stance
Pathology of imagination involves inability to properly distinguish the real from the irreal
The irreal object has a temporal structure different from real objects
Irreal changes are inefficient or radical unlike the gradual changes of perceived reality
The situation-in-the-world is the necessary condition of imagination
Situations are the different immediate modes of apprehension of the real as a world
The situation of consciousness motivates the constitution of any irreal object
The nature of the irreal object is circumscribed by this motivation from situation
Any product of artistic creation is just as irreal an object as the imaginary world it creates
The irreality of the work of art allows us to experience its world as an analogon of reality
Even a cubist painting functions as an analogon manifesting irreal objects never seen before
The novelist poet and dramatist constitute irreal objects through verbal analogons
There is a kind of overflowing in the world of things with infinitely more than we can see at every moment
To exhaust the richness of current perception would take an infinite time
For a consciousness to be capable of imagining it needs to be free
Emotion is a transformation of the world
When the paths before us become too difficult or we cannot see our way we try to change the world through magic
We live the world as though relations between things were governed not by deterministic processes but by magic
All emotions evoke the appearance of a world cruel terrible bleak or joyful in which relations are exclusively magical
Emotion is a specific manner of apprehending the world
When I am sad not just the object of my sadness but everything I perceive appears in a certain way
Emotions are intentional and strategic ways of coping with difficult situations
We choose to utilize emotions and we control them not the other way around
Emotions are not fixed and have no essence but are subject to rapid fluctuations and about-turns
Emotion is the conscious transformation by means of ones body of a situation
What changes in emotion is how the world is experienced by the subject
The world is understood as a totality of phenomena linked in a network of mutual references
Emotion is an abrupt fall of consciousness into magic
The emotions are not external forces acting upon consciousness but an action of consciousness
Consciousness tries to rearrange the world to suit itself through emotion
Emotions are a form of behavior of defeat adopted when the task is too difficult
When we cannot maintain the higher behavior appropriate to a task we adopt inferior behavior requiring lesser psychic tension
Emotional behavior is purposeful and goal-oriented not mere mechanical reflex
Man is always a sorcerer to man and the social world is primarily magical
Magic arises when we grant ordinary objects or ideas power they do not inherently possess
Emotion grabs and controls us changing our whole experience
When I am joyful that joyful emotion takes control over me and makes me want to dance and sing
When I am angry an emotion of anger takes over and makes me punch the wall
Emotion is a kind of power or energy that circulates through objects of consciousness and empowers them
The world of emotion is actually a magical world
Emotional energy transforms desires into compulsions
There may be continuous passage from unreflective instrumental world to unreflective hateful world of anger
The latter magical world is a transformation of the former instrumental world
Emotions are not diversions from ordinary activity but the very way reality is structured at the moment
Consciousness finds itself out there in a welcoming or menacing in a joyful or horrible world
Affective consciousness is a form of pre-reflective consciousness and is therefore spontaneous and self-conscious
The spontaneity of consciousness is key to understanding emotional states
Spontaneity must be distinguished from voluntary acts connected with reflective consciousness and will
Feelings have special intentionalities and represent ways of consciousness transcending itself toward the world
To hate Paul is to intend Paul as a transcendent object of consciousness
Hatred is always hatred of someone and love is always love for someone
Feelings are specific forms of intentionality constituting one way among others of transcending oneself
Feeling presents itself as a kind of knowledge of the object
If I love the long white slender hands of a person this love is one way those hands appear to my consciousness
A feeling is a distinct manner in which consciousness is directed at the world
A state is the reflective product of consciousness taking purview of its past activities
To the activity of feelings we may contrast the passivity of states
Confusing feeling with reflective states is a major source of difficulties in analyzing affective phenomena
The passive voice in describing emotions misrepresents lived experience which is unceasing engagement with a value-laden world
Affectivity should not be cast as internal self-referential occurrence disengaged from the world
A phenomenological account needs to reestablish our connection to reality through affective experience
James theory that emotions are sensations of bodily change cannot distinguish joy from anger since both involve similar modifications
We cannot distinguish emotions merely by their bodily modifications since different emotions share similar physiological profiles
Emotion has a meaning or signification or organized structure that cannot be explained as mere bodily sensation
Emotion is not a pure ineffable quality like brick-red or the feeling of pain
Emotion signifies something for my psychic life and has intentional meaning
Like the fox calling the grapes sour we project qualities onto the world through emotional transformation
We perform a conjuring act projecting new qualities onto objects through emotion
Janet treats emotion as behavior less well adapted or behavior of disadaptation
Janet associates inferior behavior with mechanical reflexes while Sartre sees it as purposeful
Some patients purposively adopt emotional behavior as a means to releasing tension
James theory reduces emotion to conscious awareness of physiological changes like heart pumping and muscles tensing
James gives a role to physiological changes in how we experience emotions which is correct
But James cannot capture the qualitative distinctiveness of each emotion through physiology alone
Psychoanalysis correctly recognizes that behavior has hidden meanings and motivations
Freud divides consciousness into conscious and unconscious which Sartre argues against
The unconscious as a thing-like entity does not account for human freedom
By showing that there is nothing in consciousness Sartre demonstrates the subject is engaged in conscious creation
With no substantial egoic object one is nothing but what one does
Conceiving of the self as a stable thing stifles the free creative project
Sartre denies that there are psychological factors beyond our consciousness that excuse behavior
Freuds theory of repression diminishes the agents responsibility for behavior
In the act of repression there must be awareness of what is being repressed
Bad faith requires conscious access to motivations while denying them
Sartrean theory makes the individual responsible for self-deception
Emotions are not to be explained as caused by unconscious drives
Desires do not indicate anything about man that he is not aware of
Desires are consciousness itself in its projective transcendent structure
Existential psychoanalysis denies the existence of the unconscious altogether
The human being is a totality expressed completely through fortuitous conduct
There is not a taste mannerism or human act which is not revealing
All conduct symbolizes and conceals in various ways the basic choice of every individual subject
Each person must be unveiled and revealed through analysis
Both psychoanalysis and existential psychoanalysis consider human beings as perpetual searching historization
The subject has no privileged capacity for self-knowledge
Conflicts and projects can be apprehended only from the point of view of the other
For Freud the libido is an irreducible psychobiological given but for Sartre choices cannot be constituted in advance
Empirical psychoanalysis is often in sight of an existential discovery but always stops part way
Emotion is one of the great attitudes or ways consciousness understands its Being-in-the-world
This follows Heideggers sense of Verstehen as understanding
Immediate reactions of horror and wonder that possess us when objects suddenly appear challenge the main theory
The world itself is unrealizable and reveals itself suddenly as a magical environment
All emotions both negative and positive are solutions to experienced difficulties
Emotions arise only when things go wrong for us when paths are blocked
Fear and anxiety must be distinguished as different affective phenomena
Anguish is awareness of oneself as a freely choosing being
Nothing beforehand can tell us how to choose or take responsibility away from us
Freedom is also a burden a terrible freedom
Emotional states and flights of imagination are active not passive despite appearances
The effort of emotional transformation is not conscious of what it is for then it would be object of reflection
Above all emotion is seizure of new relationships and new demands
Consciousness seizes or tries to seize objects otherwise transforming itself to transform the object
We must put it simply since seizing an object is impossible consciousness tries to transform itself
The emotion sets up an unbearable tension that requires magical resolution
Trying to affect constitution of things by the power of ones gaze is relying on magic
Consciousness generates its own experience with qualities unlike those of the real world
The nature of experience differs from the existing outside world because consciousness created it
Emotion is the synthetic totality of a human being in a situation
Emotion is human reality itself realizing itself in the form of emotion
Psychology has failed to give emotion its proper place in human existence
A phenomenological psychology must study the essential structures of emotional experience
The phenomenological description reveals the essence of emotions
Being is divided into two incommunicable regions: being-in-itself and being-for-itself
Being-in-itself is concrete lacks the ability to change and is unaware of itself
Being-in-itself is the pure plenitude of objects characterized by full positivity
Being-in-itself simply is what it is with no internal differentiation or diversity
Being is complete fullness of existence a meaningless mass of matter devoid of consciousness
The in-itself is not exhausted in any of its particular phenomenal aspects
Being-in-itself lies beyond our experience of it and we can only say that it is
Being-for-itself is the being of consciousness characterized by lack and incompleteness
The for-itself is conscious of its own consciousness but is also incomplete
Being-for-itself is a nothingness of being a lack of being
The for-itself is none other than the nothingness that encounters being
Intentional consciousness is initially empty a void filled through being conscious of the world
The for-itself is a being in situation that has a certain grasp on the world and shapes itself through it
The for-itself is a project constantly making itself through its actions
The for-itself is not determined since it is a nothingness distinguishing itself from the world
The for-itself is entirely free to become through its actions
Consciousness is always and essentially consciousness of something
Consciousness transcends itself to reach an object outside itself
If there is nothing besides consciousness nothing of which it can be conscious it ceases to exist
To be conscious of something is to confront a concrete and full presence that is not itself consciousness
Pure subjectivity would dissolve into nothingness without objects to intend
Consciousness does not make sense by itself but arises only as awareness of objects
Consciousness is not a thing or substance but an activity directed at the world
Consciousness is nothing but intentionality an activity directed at the world
Nothingness is an experienced reality and cannot be a merely subjective mistake
The absence of a friend and absence of money hint at a being of nothingness
It is through human consciousness that nothingness comes into the world
Nothingness is not an abstract idea complementary to being nor conceived outside being
Nothingness must be given at the heart of being and demands a host with full positivity of being
Nothingness borrows its power of nihilation from the being it inhabits
Being-for-itself is the origin of negation bringing nothingness into the world
By bringing nothingness into the world consciousness changes its relation to being without annihilating it
Every question brings up the possibility of a negative answer of non-being
The human attitude of inquiry puts consciousness at distance from the world
Humans introduce the possibility of destruction and fragility into the world
Non-being can neither be part of the being-in-itself nor can it be as a complement of it
Nothingness is dependent upon being in a way that being is not dependent upon nothingness
There is a pre-comprehension of non-being that is the condition of negative judgements
What occasions nothingness in human beings is freedom
Freedom is not a property attached to human nature but is the nature of humankind itself
There is no difference between ones being and ones being-free
The very being of the for-itself is freedom which is condemned to be free
One must forever choose for oneself and therefore make oneself
We are condemned to be free because we must constantly make choices without ultimate guidelines
Freedom is a poisoned gift plunging the for-itself deep into anguish
If freedom is absolute then responsibility is also absolute
One is responsible for everything except for the fact of ones responsibility
One is free but not free to obliterate fully ones freedom
This abandonment to freedom is an expression of ones facticity
One is condemned to be wholly responsible for oneself
Because I can break with my past I am entirely responsible for it
Whatever I have done before I have freely chosen and must be held responsible for it
Freedom always interpenetrates facticity making one wholly responsible for oneself
Freedom to obtain refers to our ability to act in certain ways in the practical world
Freedom to choose refers to fundamental projects we set and meanings we confer on situations
A person with no legs is not free to walk but is free in how they relate to that fact
Freedom is always restricted by the situation in which it is abandoned
Even in facticity the for-itself perpetually relates itself to itself in freedom
The consciousness of freedom is disclosed in anxiety
It is in anxiety that man gets the consciousness of his freedom
Anxiety is the mode of being of freedom as consciousness of being
In anxiety freedom is in its being in question of itself
An internal connection exists among nothingness freedom and anxiety
The for-itself discovers its own freedom in anguish
In most everyday situations we are acting without anguish caught up in things without reflection
Even in spontaneous acts there remains the possibility of putting the act into question
The gambler experiences anguish because his past decision to stop has no causal force on his present
The mountain climber paralyzed by vertigo experiences nothing can stop him from throwing himself over
Anguish attests to our diasporic divided being which is our freedom
Facticity is all the concrete details against which human freedom exists and is limited
Facticity includes birthplace time body personal history and concrete circumstances not chosen
Without facticity consciousness could choose its attachments and would be absolute unfettered freedom
The for-itself apprehends itself as a lack or decompression of being not its own foundation
It is a hole in the heart of being infected with nothingness abandoned without justification
The for-itself discovers itself thrown into a situation buffeted by brute contingencies
The for-itself is for the most part superfluous and in the way
Facticity indicates the utter contingency and irrevocable situationality of the being of the for-itself
How we relate to facts of our situation is our freedom even if those facts are given
A physical disability is facticity but how one interprets and lives with it is freedom
One does not become a bourgeois or French person until one chooses to become such
Existence precedes essence
Who you are your essence is defined by what you do your existence
The for-itself lacks a predetermined essence and is forced to create itself from nothingness
A tree is a tree and lacks the ability to change or create its being
Man on the other hand makes himself by acting in the world
Instead of simply being as the in-itself does the for-itself must actuate its own being
The for-itself is a being which is what it is not and is not what it is
Bad faith is ones self-deception about the human reality
Bad faith can take the form of making oneself falsely believe not to be what one actually is
Bad faith can take the form of conceiving oneself as an object thereby denying freedom
In bad faith one must believe that social role is equivalent to human existence
Living defined by occupation social racial or economic class is the essence of bad faith
In bad faith people cannot transcend their situations to realize what they must be
Bad faith is the condition in which one does not realize one is human not just a waiter or grocer
The waiter plays at being a waiter with movements a little too precise a little too rapid
The waiter applies himself to changing his movements as if they were mechanisms
He gives himself the quickness and pitiless rapidity of things
The waiter is playing at being a waiter in a cafe
By reducing oneself to a fixed predefined social role one lives in bad faith
Society demands that a tradesman limit himself to his function
The waiter is a waiter in the mode of being what he is not
A woman on a first date knows the mans intentions but wants to remain oblivious
She wants to postpone the moment when she will have to make a decision
The man grabs her hand and she leaves it there but does not notice she is leaving it
She makes of herself a disembodied mind denying her own facticity her embodied being
The homosexual who denies being homosexual is in bad faith
By denying ones homosexuality one plays on being as if one were not what one is
The champion of sincerity demanding confession is also in bad faith
Sincerity is being what one is but this is impossible for the for-itself
One plays at being sincere which is another instance of bad faith
In both bad faith and sincerity one is aiming at being in-itself fleeing ones own being
The being of the human being is bad faith
Authenticity is a human possibility though Sartre does not explain how to achieve it
Authenticity consists in choosing in a way that reflects the nature of the for-itself as transcendence and facticity
Authenticity involves a proper coordination of transcendence and facticity
Authenticity avoids uncoordinated expression of the desire for being
Authenticity is choosing in a way that reveals the for-itself as both factual and transcendent
Being-for-others is a new dimension in which the self exists as an object for others
Each for-itself seeks to recover its own being by making an object out of the other
One can see everyone but oneself which is the tragedy of intersubjectivity
My very existence depends on the other on the most foundational level
Being-seen-by-another is a constitutive part of experience
The other is there from the beginning not added on to a solitary subject later
The Look demonstrates how the self gains thematic awareness of the body
Through the look one forms a public and self-conscious sense of how the body appears to others
It is through the look that one obtains self-consciousness in the one being looked at
The shock of encountering the other is a revelation of the existence of my body as an in-itself for the other
The look of the other objectifies me making me see myself as an object
We perceive ourselves being perceived and come to objectify ourselves as we are being objectified
The gaze of the other robs us of our inherent freedom
We deprive ourselves of existence as a being-for-itself and falsely self-identify as a being-in-itself
To be looked at is to apprehend oneself as the unknown object of unknowable appraisals
Being-seen constitutes me as a defenseless being for a freedom which is not my freedom
I am a slave to the degree that my being is dependent on a freedom which is not mine
The others look is my transcendence transcended
Before being seen I was a pure transcendence not willing to define or judge my acts
After being seen my transcendence has been transcended
Shame is the recognition that I am indeed that object which the other is looking at and judging
I can be ashamed only as my freedom escapes me to become a given object
In the experience of shame the objectification of my ego denies my existence as a subject
Shame is a moral emotion akin to guilt where the judgement of others teaches me I have transgressed
Shame is a mode of self-evaluation through which I can see and judge myself
Shame is an ontological structure of subjectivity and intersubjectivity
Original shame gives us the capacity for reflective self-consciousness
The existence of other minds is established a priori through conscious states such as shame
By reacting against the look of the other I can turn him into an object for my look
This is no stable relation as the objectification oscillates between self and other
The essence of relations between consciousnesses is not Mitsein being-with but conflict
It is useless for human reality to escape this dilemma: transcend the other or be transcended
We ceaselessly oscillate between objectifying the other and wanting to be objectified
In the love relationship the beloved is not simply a thing one desires to possess
Love expresses a special kind of appropriation different from ownership
The lover wants to assimilate the love of the beloved without destroying the others freedom
Love is a concrete manifestation of the fundamental project to be God
Through love we seek to possess the freedom of the other as the ground of our identity
Love aims at an absolute unity between lovers a merging of two free consciousnesses
The unity with the other as a ground of my being is an unattainable end an impossible project
Two consciousnesses can never encounter each other qua free consciousnesses
The lover is perpetually in danger of being made to appear as an object
Love cannot be reciprocal as the beloved also wants to be worshipped by the lover
There is perpetual dissatisfaction of the lover even in the greatest love affairs
Masochists put themselves forward as an in-itself for the other
Masochists set up conditions so that they can be assimilated by the other
Masochists deliberately transform themselves into an object
In masochism we attempt to turn our body into a fascinating object for the other
Masochism leaves ourselves dependent on our facticity and vulnerable to the others look
Sadists seek to incarnate the other by using their body as a tool
The other becomes an instrument in the sadists hands appropriating the others freedom
In sadism we try to destroy the others transcendence by reducing them to pure flesh
Sadism fails because the other can always turn back and make objects out of sadists
Sadism and masochism are the two reefs on which desire may flounder
Normal sexual activity is commonly designated as sadomasochistic
Sexual desire produces a defined polarity represented by sadism and masochism
This system often mistakenly called love is emotional alienation and denial of freedom
The purpose of either participant is not to exist but to maintain the others looking at them
Alienation can become so intense that participants cause pain to prove control over the others look
Sexual desire cultivates a unique state of consciousness where one is simultaneously subject and object
Desire is an ontological fundamental aspect of life
In sex we try to bring the beloveds consciousness to the surface of their body by magical acts
At the moment of orgasm the illusion is ended and we return to ourselves
Man is a useless passion to be the ens causa sui the God of the ontological proof
Each of us exists within an overall condition of nothingness that allows for free consciousness
Within our being we are constrained to make continuous conscious choices
This dichotomy causes anguish because choice represents a limit on freedom
We seek to flee anguish through action-oriented constructs like escapes visualizations or visions
We often become unconscious actors doing as we must to fulfill our chosen characters destinies
Man is haunted by a vision of completion the ens causa sui which many identify as God
The for-itself aims for another mode of being the for-itself-in-itself but this is unrealizable
The human condition is dominated by the irrationality of particular projects
The for-itself strives to absorb the in-itself but the in-itself can never be possessed
I am a nothingness a lack dehumanized by the other and deceived even by myself
Yet I am free I am transcendent I am consciousness and I make the world
The self needs projects which can be viewed as aspects of the fundamental project
The source of the fundamental project is a spontaneous original choice depending on freedom
The motivation for the fundamental project lies within consciousness as a desire for being
The individual choice of fundamental project is an original choice
An understanding of Flaubert must involve an attempt to decipher his original choice
The fundamental project is fully experienced by the subject and wholly conscious
But the fundamental project need not be known by the subject
Existential psychoanalysis concentrates on humanitys fundamental project
Existential psychoanalysis consists in understanding the meaning of conduct in light of free choice
Psychoanalysis reveals what makes an individual a unity through their original choice
Every taste mannerism or human act is revealing of the fundamental project
Determinist explanations conceal ones free project and obliterate responsibility
Freuds differing metapsychological pictures split the subject in two or more
Freud reifies the structure of consciousness attempting a mechanistic explanation of bad faith
Freud simply transfers the problem to another level where it remains unsolved
The postulation of a censor is redundant as we encounter the same problem of consciousness hiding from itself
What Freud identifies as repression is indicative of the larger structure of bad faith
Hiding something from oneself occurs at the level of consciousness as a unified phenomenon
The notion of an unconscious consciousness is an outright contradiction
If I break under torture I am totally and unavoidably responsible for that deed
I am just as responsible as if I had volunteered the information on my own
There are no excuses based on upbringing social or economic situation or past behavior patterns
Man is responsible for all men not just himself
Abandonment means we have no guidelines no excuse nothing to help us decide
Despair accompanies freedom as we cannot rely on external forces or higher powers
The body for itself relates to facticity and the first-person attempt to transcend it
The body for the other is the individual objectified from the third-person point of view
The body for itself as known by the other combines both cases under the others gaze
Our engagement with the world is one in which the body is constantly at play and implicit in action
To have an understanding of ourselves necessitates the presence of others
Consciousness is fundamentally an intersubjective experience
The lived body escapes us because it is always out there and not just in here
Hell is other people because the others look can collapse us from being to thing
We see ourselves from the perspective of the other and self-consciously collapse from pour-soi to en-soi
The world which is truly human comes from the encounter between for-itself and in-itself
Consciousness enters the world through the for-itself and brings nothingness negation and difference
Consciousness is what allows the world to exist
Without consciousness there would be no objects no trees no rivers only being
Phenomenology eliminated dualisms replacing them with the monism of the phenomenon
All appearances are of equal value in phenomenology
There is no noumena or thing-in-itself hidden behind phenomenal appearances
Husserls transcendental ego is useless and disastrous leading to solipsism
Heidegger neglects the phenomenon of the lived body
Heidegger has no explanation for the concrete relatedness of selves
The pre-reflective cogito is the primary consciousness and Sartres original point of departure
The pre-reflective cogito is non-personal
There is only consciousness of something not I am conscious of the chair
The ego or self is posited by the projecting activity of the for-itself
Without the world there is no ego and without the ego there is no world
Value is the in-itself-for-itself the impossible unity that motivates all projects
Values are not pre-established by God or nature but are something for which we are responsible
The individual must make values himself and shape himself as he acts
No values are found already made in the world
Existence precedes essence is the first principle of existentialism
Man first exists encounters himself surges up in the world and defines himself afterwards
There is no human nature since there is no God to conceive it
Man is nothing other than what he makes of himself
Man will be what he purposes to be and what he wills himself to be after being thrown into existence
Before the projection of the self nothing exists not even in the heaven of intelligence
A paper knife has an essence that precedes its existence because it is designed before created
The concept of man in the mind of God is comparable to the concept of paper knife in the mind of the artisan
Atheistic existentialism declares that God does not exist yet there is a being whose existence precedes essence
If God does not exist there is at least one being which exists before it can be defined by any concept and this being is man
If God did not exist everything would be permitted and this is the starting point of existentialism
Everything is indeed permitted if God does not exist
If God does not exist we are not provided with any values or commands that could legitimize our behavior
There can no longer be any good a priori since there is no infinite and perfect consciousness to think it
It is nowhere written that the good exists that one must be honest or must not lie
The existentialist finds it extremely embarrassing that God does not exist
With God disappears all possibility of finding values in an intelligible heaven
Man is condemned to be free
Condemned because he did not create himself yet is nevertheless at liberty
From the moment he is thrown into this world he is responsible for everything he does
There is no determinism man is free man is freedom
Man is free but not free to not be free
Man cannot not be free there is a form of necessity for freedom which can never be given up
One will never be able to explain ones action by reference to a given and specific human nature
We have neither behind us nor before us in a luminous realm of values any means of justification or excuse
We are left alone without excuse
Man discovers forthwith that he is without excuse
The first effect of existentialism is that it puts every man in possession of himself as he is
Existentialism places the entire responsibility for existence squarely upon ones own shoulders
When we say that man is responsible for himself we mean he is responsible for all men
In choosing for himself man chooses for all men
There is not one action which is not creative at the same time of an image of man such as he believes he ought to be
To choose between this or that is at the same time to affirm the value of that which is chosen
We are unable ever to choose the worse what we choose is always the better
Nothing can be better for us unless it is better for all
Our responsibility is much greater than we had supposed for it concerns mankind as a whole
In fashioning myself I fashion man
If I decide to marry I am committing not only myself but humanity as a whole to the practice of monogamy
I am creating a certain image of man as I would have him to be
The existentialist frankly states that man is in anguish
Anguish arises when a man commits himself fully realizing he is choosing for the whole of mankind
In such a moment a man cannot escape from the sense of complete and profound responsibility
Many who show no anxiety are merely disguising their anguish or are in flight from it
If you dont feel anxiety when you make decisions you are forgetting your total and deep responsibility
Anguish is the result of knowing one is condemned to live life with no safety net
Anguish is awareness of the radically indeterminate nature of human existence
All leaders know that anguish but it does not prevent their acting
Anguish is the very condition of action for it presupposes a plurality of possibilities
In choosing one possibility they realize it has value only because it is chosen
Anguish makes explicit our responsibility towards other men
Far from being a screen separating us from action anguish is a condition of action itself
This is the anguish of Abraham commanded to sacrifice his son and wondering is this truly an angel
When we speak of abandonment we mean that God does not exist and we must draw the consequences to the end
The existentialist is strongly opposed to secular moralism which seeks to suppress God at the least possible expense
Man is forlorn for he cannot find anything to depend upon either within or outside himself
Abandonment implies that we ourselves decide our being
With this abandonment goes anguish
Abandonment is the loneliness atheists feel when they realize there is no God to prescribe a way of life
We are abandoned in the sense of being alone in the universe and the arbiters of our own essence
Despair means that we limit ourselves to reliance upon that which is within our wills
Despair means relying only on the sum of probabilities which render our action feasible
One does not rely upon any possibilities beyond those strictly concerned in ones action
Beyond the point at which possibilities cease to affect my action I ought to disinterest myself
There is no God and no prevenient design which can adapt the world and all its possibilities to my will
We must act without hope as Descartes meant
I cannot rely on others to later take up my deeds and carry them forward
Others may come after me and establish Fascism
Things will be as man will have decided they are to be
A student came to me torn between staying with his mother and joining the Free French Forces
He found himself confronted by two very different modes of action one concrete and immediate the other addressing a greater end
No established ethical system could help this student decide which was more important
By what authority in the name of what golden rule could he decide to abandon or stay with his mother
There are no means of judging the content is always concrete and unpredictable
He was obliged to invent the law for himself
To choose an adviser is nevertheless to commit oneself by that choice
Feeling is formed by the deeds that one does therefore I cannot consult it as a guide to action
Man is nothing other than the sum of his actions his life
Quietism is the attitude of people who say let others do what I cannot do
The doctrine I present is precisely the opposite there is reality only in action
Man is nothing else but what he does
There is no genius other than that which is expressed in works of art
The genius of Proust is the works of Proust
A coward is responsible for his cowardice because he has made himself a coward by his actions
A hero makes himself heroic by his deeds
People would prefer to be born a coward or be born a hero
Man makes himself he is not found ready-made
Man makes himself by the choice of his morality and he cannot but choose a morality
Those who hide their freedom behind deterministic excuses I shall call cowards
Those who try to show that their existence is necessary when it is merely an accident I shall call scum
Neither cowards nor scum can be identified except upon the plane of strict authenticity
There is no sense in life a priori
Life is nothing until it is lived but it is yours to make sense of
The value of life is nothing else but the sense that you choose
Having removed God the Father someone must invent values
We have to take things as they are
Although the content of morality is variable a certain form of this morality is universal
Principles that are too abstract break down when we come to defining action
There is a human universality but it is not something given it is being perpetually made
I make this universality in choosing myself
What is at the heart of existentialism is the absolute character of free commitment
In willing freedom we discover that it depends entirely upon the freedom of others
I cannot make liberty my aim unless I make that of others equally my aim
I cannot not will the freedom of others
Existentialism is a humanism because man is all the time outside of himself
It is in projecting and losing himself beyond himself that man makes man to exist
It is by pursuing transcendent aims that man can realize himself as truly human
Man is himself the heart and center of his transcendence
There is no legislator but man himself and he himself thus abandoned must decide for himself
Existentialism is nothing else but an attempt to draw the full conclusions from a consistently atheistic position
The universe is the universe of human subjectivity
Existentialism is not despair but is optimistic and liberating
What is alarming in existentialism is that it confronts man with a possibility of choice
Existentialism is the sternness of optimism not pessimism
Mans destiny lies within himself
Marxism is the philosophy of our time and the unsurpassable horizon of contemporary thought
Marxism needs to be resuscitated from the moribund state that Soviet dogma left it in
Existentialism can be integrated with Marxism to create a more complete philosophy
Orthodox Marxism became boringly determinist by forgetting the dialectical interplay between agency and structure
Men make their history on the basis of real prior conditions but it is men who make it not the prior conditions
The movement of human praxis goes beyond prior conditions while conserving them
Dialectical materialism remains a mere skeleton if it does not integrate certain Western disciplines
Historical materialism needs to be supplemented by a focus on human action in the face of adversity
Sartre rejects the teleology that characterizes Marxist history
Sartre opposes all forms of mechanical dialectical thought
The rigid base-superstructure dichotomy of traditional Marxism must be rejected
Economism reduces historical processes to passive reflections of material forces
Praxis is the mediating term where human freedom engages with scarcity and inertia
Man is action he is a practical organism
Man is only as a becoming
Human action presupposes a material agent and the material organization of an enterprise on matter through matter
Praxis is the instrumentalization of material reality
Praxis envelopes the inanimate thing in a totalizing project that imposes on it a pseudo-organic unity
The dialectic is the individual career of the object not a pre-ordained schema imposed from without
Action is dialectic
To assert the priority of action over being is to assert the priority of praxis over the practico-inert
Without work there would be no mode of production
The priority of praxis itself over worked matter is the ground principle
Free conscious activity of individuals forms the foundation of common praxis
Totalisation is the dialectical structure of praxis of conscious human action
Totalisation makes the notion of time possible which totality does not
History is totalisation or it is nothing
Totalisation is the act by which a social movement constitutes itself as a subject of its own activity
Conscious human acts are movements toward totalization
The sense of human acts is co-determined by existing social conditions
Through multiplicities totalisation continues synthetic labour making each part an expression of the whole
Totalisation is a developing activity which cannot cease without multiplicity reverting to its original statute
History is a detotalized totality an incomplete and ongoing synthesis forged by multiple praxes
Scarcity is the negative unity of the human multiplicity
Scarcity realises the passive totality of individuals as the impossibility of coexisting
Scarcity manifests as the possibility of a common destruction of all mankind
Every satisfaction of a need can cause antagonism under conditions of scarcity
Scarcity deprives people of the ability to make particular choices and diminishes their humanity
Social relationships are dominated by scarcity
Humans live their history in a situation dominated by a milieu of scarcity and necessity
Need is the primordial relation of the dialectic of individual organic action
Man is a practical organism with material needs
The practico-inert is the realm of worked matter sedimented praxis passivity and counterfinality
The practico-inert is matter as the negation of action
Alienation is our experience of the materialised result
Alienation is the negative moment in which one is produced in passivity by what the practico-inert makes of what one has made
As a wage labourer the worker is a worked Thing
Worked matter is the inert meaning of the worker
In factory production the worker is the object of the machine
The worker adapts to the machine destroying bodily rhythms by interiorising a rhythm which is absolutely other
The practico-inert is the site of violence darkness and magic
Worked matter reflects our activity back to us as inertia and our inertia as our activity
All matter conditions human praxis through the passive unity of prefabricated meanings
The practico-inert structures collective behaviour through the false naturalization of prevailing institutions
Counterfinality is the reversal of the finality intended by an agent
Praxis becomes absorbed in passive and inert syntheses of innumerable other actions
Human finality reappears as counterfinality as a negation of human ends
The Chinese peasant who cuts wood creates flooding and famines through the absence of forests
The produced object reflects the entire society
This world in which I no longer recognise myself is a world I have created
Freedom in the Critique means the necessity of living constraints in the form of exigencies fulfilled by praxis
People are neither absolutely free to determine the meaning of their acts nor slaves to circumstances
We always make something of what is made of us
The choice whether to accept capitalism or revolt is ultimately our free choice situated in our condition
Even as we are oppressed we are always responsible for ourselves
There is a form of necessity for freedom which can never be given up
Seriality is a loose collection of individuals brought together by a common situation or activity
In seriality individuals exist as a loose collection focused solely on self-gain leading to isolation
The majority of people are alienated from one another for the majority of time
What people lack in seriality is praxis the will to get involved in the political process
In serial relations unity is always elsewhere
Seriality is impotent action or inactive practice
The working class as observed is merely a sociological category or passive collective
The group-in-fusion is a group of people united by a common purpose
The group-in-fusion is the dissolution of the series into a fused group
The fused group is the direct opposite of alterity
In the Apocalypse synthetic unity is always here not elsewhere
In a group the presence of others expands my power we become capable of things impossible in isolation
In a group-in-fusion each individual can occupy the position of the quasi-sovereign
Unlike in seriality where power is always elsewhere in a group destiny is decided in the here and now
The group-in-fusion is not innocent it can refer to both progressive and fascistic social movements
The storming of the Bastille shows how a series is suddenly transformed into a group-in-fusion
Freedom was manifested as the necessity of dissolving necessity
The pledge binds individuals in an organized group promising mutual protection of practical freedom
The pledge is the group developing its own internal form of power and sanction
In the pledged group power arises from the group itself to fight against serialitys impersonal violence
Through the creative act of the pledge and the statute of Terror we have become brothers
Fraternity-Terror is the attempt to maintain group cohesion and prevent dissolution at all costs
The violence that Fraternity-Terror generates spills over onto the groups own members
A standing organization is inaugurated through a pledge where members vow to remain in solidarity
Organizations retain the organic vitalism of fused groups yet adhere to formalist precepts
Organizations are both fused and formal
Organization refers to the internal action by which a group defines its structures
Large organizations can still facilitate fused praxis without reverting to institutionalization
Organized groups enhance the individuals practical freedom
Institutions are atrophied group formations
Organizations are frequently corrupted especially if they ossify into institutions
The function of the institution pre-determines how the individual is to act
There are few guarantees that social revolt will end well
The French Revolution descending into Terror and the Russian Revolution producing Stalinism exemplify group degeneration
Collectives are practico-inert objects purely material and inorganic despite appearances
Unlike groups which can do and say things collectives are merely passive syntheses
Class is being or social being as materiality class as ones prefabricated reality and destiny
Nation is our being-outside-ourselves in matter producing us and awaiting us from birth
As a collective the nation can do nothing it doesnt speak or want to know
The sleight of hand in nationalism is the illusion that nations exist and act like organised groups
There is no dialectic of nature only human action is dialectical
Whether a dialectic of nature exists is a scientific endeavor not a philosophical enquiry
Dialectics arise solely from material human activity amid scarcity not from any inherent cosmic logic
The precedence of matter over consciousness is antithetical to dialectical humanism
Psychoanalytic thought can be a useful device to enliven and actualize Marxist analysis
Notions of alienation and reification arise first in childhood and are projected onto working lives
The analysis must focus on how economic conditions shape the individual and how psychological forces lead to action
The dialectical tension between progressive and regressive moments produces a surpassing of existing possibilities
